ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Earliest units on genetics were informative.
A rundown of a good handful of biology topics, and insight into how to discuss social issues related to biology
learned a lot about connections between biology and the world around us in a way that isn't only solely STEM-oriented
I learned about many different biology-related world issues that we face today, such as GMOs, COVID, CRISPR, DNA privacy, and more.
General insight to biology that is involved in real life situations.
Interesting topics in modern medicine!

I developed a background knowledge of basic biological concepts and mechanisms, and an understanding of various relevant topics ranging from aging and Alzheimer's to COVID to genetically modified organisms.
Biology and society
Scientific comprehension and writing
I learned of many different and relevant biological topics from this course. I think my main takeaway would be my new understanding of neurological pathways affected by drug use, stress, and joy.
I learned a lot about many of the most pressing contemporary topics in biology, including gene editing and COVID-19.
A great overview of a variety of biological issues, allowing me to get a better sense of how the world around me works (in a biological sense).

I was able to understand the basics of various biology topics such as microbiomes, cancer, and the COVID pandemic. I learned how to write a proper research/argument paper that I feel could benefit me later in school as well.
I enjoyed going more in-depth on biology concepts. The essays were great to focus on a particular biological issue and explore it.

this is pretty much a biology course so if you wanted to take a science credit that was more interesting or social science-y then this might not be for you. The psets were pretty hard depending on the professor but the papers were very interesting and easy to work on.

Basic biology knowledge ranging from plants, to human anatomy in particular nerves and the nervous system, as well as drugs and disease. Helpful foundations for humanities/social sciences majors interested in issues like health policy.
I learned a basic foundation of biological concepts that are applicable to current events

I learned about biology in relevant ways that connected to the world today, especially in regards to coronavirus and genetics. We went through molecular and cell biology, diseases, plants and environmental aspects, genetic engineering, modern medicine, and diseases (off the top of my head). I learned how to analytically think and search scientifically reputable information to further my knowledge. I also learned how to write a scientific research paper (style and content-wise).
I learned about different scientific issues such as infectious disease, cancer biology, stem cell research, climate change, etc and their social impacts
I learned a lot about the fundamental focuses of biology
This course gave me a decent introduction to various biological concepts I'd previously had no understanding of.
I learned more about biological concepts and how we can implement different strategies to combat them.
I learned about some basic biological concepts.
Learned about the biology behind relevant topics such as viruses
Good basic knowledge of concepts in biology and new developments in the field.
Misc. intro biology topics.
I learned basic biology concepts and their relevance to current events. Also how to research science.
basic biology and how my body works
This course gave a great introduction to the necessary biological fundamentals.
An overview of lots of different aspects of biology-- evolution, neurotransmission, climate change, and much more-- with a specific eye to social/governmental applications of scientific info
I learned a ton about current viruses and issues in our world which was extremely interesting.
General background in relevant biological topics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the strength of the course were the two papers that allowed students to choose a scientific topic of their choice. I learned a lot about the topics I wrote about and had a chance to write about science from a social science perspective.
I liked getting lectures by different professors who were experts in their fields!

Strengths: manageable workload, incredible teaching team, and very engaging material
Weaknesses: each lecture felt too in-depth for the breath-nature of the course
I thought it was a very engaging course
Well structured!
I think this course is structured well. I liked that we had two papers rather than exams, and I enjoyed the Biology, the World, and You series.
Sometimes harsh grading not clear expectations
Strengths: great content and organized course
The biggest strength is section. It's engaging and helps elucidate the topics we learned about in class.

This course was a very good class. I liked how they incorporated different professors to teach different subjects that they excelled in. Each did a great job teaching the material and used polls and questions to keep students engaged. I couldn't really find any flaws in the course. Given the circumstances, I felt they did the best job possible.
Depending on the professor and topic, lectures could be extremely boring and not engaging. The problem sets also varied in difficulty depending on the professor teaching the material.

The psets varied too much by professor. Some psets had nothing to do with the lectures and you really had to look up the answers on google and hope you got it right. I didn't like how the TA's and professors did not change the structure or grading of the pset despite the fact that alot of us complained. This is a science class for non-stem majors but they graded us harshly like were stem students.

Strengths: fits a lot of content into one semester! It really is a crash course on biology that's relevant to society. The topics covered are interesting, and I really liked the Biology, the world and You sessions which focused on topics we asked about.

Weaknesses: The quality of lecturing was a little uneven between the many lectures. Prof Bamanyar is an excellent and engaging lecturer, but Professor Engelmans and Prof Paulsens lectures were a little bit too dense/information-dumpy for me as a nonscience major, and would contain a lot of detail that sometimes felt extraneous to understanding the biological processes being taught. Prof Bamanyar uses simplistic cartoons and comics to help clarify things and explain things in lay terms, which helps with conceptual understandings and makes things more accessible.

The problem sets are also very very specific, often requiring referring back to lectures (especially for Professor Paulsens lectures). Professor Yannicks lectures are straightforward enough that the problem sets should be answerable based on notes. I'm not sure how I would have managed the problem sets if I wasn't able to refer back to the recorded lectures!

Strengths: the wide variety of topics! Everyone is bound to be interested in some of them
Areas for improvements: Sometimes there was a level of biology knowledge assumed that was much higher than reality so it was hard to follow.

Strengths: the material Weaknesses: too much at once... lengthy weekly problem sets on top of the lectures and section and 2 papers during the pandemic led to frustration and burn out during the semester.
PSets often did not reflect what we learned in lecture and were graded way too harshly.

Strengths: gave an wide overview of the different fields of biology 
Weaknesses: psets varied in difficulty based on the professors and some of them were very diifficult given that the students in the class are non-science majors
I liked this course a lot

I think that the weaknesses of this course stem mainly from the breadth it attempts to cover. I had a hard time engaging with the material when we moved on to a different broad scientific topic every week. Compounded with the changing professors and the focus in discussion section on superficial social and ethical concerns rather than going deeper into the science, it was difficult for me to further explore scientific thinking. This course might be better if it had explored only one or two of the topics, say the opioid epidemic or social issues and COVID or the politics of gene editing.

A strength of the course was that it was engaging and the administrators made a real effort to have students interests represented. A weakness was that lectures were not required to be attended so it was somewhat easy to not participate.

As a non-STEM major, I found this course interesting and engaging. Overall, its strength is the variety of teaching staff, experiences, and topics covered. Its weaknesses were relatively minor in comparison.
Easy-to-follow lectures with the opportunity to ask questions and discussion sections consisted of interesting topics with a lot of engagement

Strengths were the passion of the instructors and teaching fellows, as well as the Biology, the World, and YOU lectures. Weakness might be how harsh some of the early problem sets especially were graded.

Strengths- Lots of social topic coverage in the sections; sections felt interesting and based on student input. Some bonus point opportunities. Bio and You sessions are fun.
Weaknesses- Depending on TF, harsh grading. Psets are graded like tests, which means little points dropping from the grade frequently. Not great communication about paper expectations.

The strengths of the course were the sections and the special sessions. A weakness of the course was the occasional inconsistency in pset format and difficulty; as well as sometimes a lack of clarity in pset questions

strengths - interesting topics
weakness - lectures were essentially unnecessary and students did not need to watch lectures to pass
This course was great in that the lectures were informative and interesting.

This class was excellently designed. The lectures were approachable but still engaging, and we were exposed to a lot of actual scientific scholarship. The course format gave us a wide breadth, and although we did do some original thinking in each week's pset, we didnt need to track the same themes the whole time. Was super engaging as a humanities person in science. 
The grade structure and section is a definite plus-- extremely manageable as a 5th class.
I only found strengths. I thought the sections were excellent.
Very salient lectures, clear expectations. No weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: virtual lecture was good!
Recorded lectures
The course was configured well in terms of its online format. I appreciated that we could re-watch the lectures on Canvas afterward.
Good set up

I felt like most practices in this course were successful. Again, the change in professors kept it interesting and engaging. They also did a good job organizing slides and making sure all the info was presented. At times, I felt like the presentation was a bit fast, but this could easily be overlooked because I was able to go back and rewatch the recorded lecture.

I liked the online format. I thought the class was structured well to allow non-bio students to learn about biological concepts without needing to understand complicated processes to do well in the course.

Great: recorded lectures, as the lectures were VERY info/content-heavy and it was helpful to refer back.
Could be improved: It was a lot of content to absorb via Zoom.

I liked the section format, especially with the activities and the breakout rooms. They helped me solidify and further integrate the information that I learned. I also liked the way the lectures were organized and easy to follow (with slides and recordings after).
I liked when we had polls during lectures because it made class more interactive
I thought this system worked well
Some course practices that allowed for virtual engagement were surveys.
The implementation of lecture recordings was a fantastic adaptation to the pandemic.
Lectures were easily available for students who could not tune in synchronously
Class was organized as well as possible given the circumstances.

section - great reading prep but too long and demanding
lecture - great topics 
grades - TAs were too strict and did not want to help those without a science background.
The Biology, the world, and you sessions were the most engaging!
Asynchronous options for the lectures were great. We could work on our own time, but still stay connected with the class through section.
I thought that the zoom lectures were excellent.
Sections were great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. At least as it was developed as a virtual class, it was generally disorganized and not conducive to learning.

This class is not challenging intellectually but the grading was way too hard for no reason at all. There were 10 weekly psets and it was virtually impossible to receive full credit on any of them. Very nit picky grading. If you need a science credit, not a terrible option, but there's probably better guts out there. I did like how the professors rotated, it kept things fresh and new.

Yes, especially for non-science or STEM majors, this class was a reasonably accessible and engaging course that gives students an opportunity to explore the topics that interest them most (at least in this classs current iteration).
yes! really interesting science class! take it- you'll learn a lot, material is interesting, and workload isn't bad

Yes!! All the issues we discussed were incredibly relevant and important for anyone to know. I also feel that anyone remotely interested in biology and who needs a science credit should take this course.
Yes if you need an easy science credit.
Definitely. If you are interested in biology but want a more of a survey course take it.
Yes! I liked the course structure
Do not take this course. It is not a gut science credit. Although it is advertised for non-STEM students, the grading is extremely tough.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student who is interested in biology but doesn't have much experience with it, or who wants or needs to take a science credit but does not consider themselves a "science person."
Sure
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. This course is properly suited towards those who want a comprehensive knowledge of recent topics in biology, but are not tailored toward the biology major.
I would recommend this course to a non-stem student interested in biology.
Yes I would, especially to a student that isn't all that comfortable with the sciences in general. It's a great way to get your Sc credit, and you learn some really interesting things along the way.
I owuld
Yes, great class.
Yes! If you are okay with taking a biology course for your science credit.

I would recommend this to students who are nonscience majors who are able to put in a bit of time and work to this. Although there were no exams, which was great, the problem sets required referring back to the lectures as they were very specific. 

However, if this class has exams in the post-COVID version of this class, I would warn against taking this class if you have a full workload, as there is a LOT of content to memorize.
Yes! A great way for non-stem students to have a basic understanding of current events. The two papers in particular were great because they allowed you to explore anything that interested you.

I would recommend the course to another student, but not during the pandemic. I found myself drowning in work with difficult classes and thought that this would be a nice introductory course to balance the workload out, but it was not the case. Combined with my other courses, it contributed to burnout.
Yes because you learn a lot about different biological topics but this is not a gut and takes some time to complete assignments
Yes, absolutely take this course if you want to have a better understanding of the natural world and the human body!
Yes

I don't think I would. There are so many better courses for non-science majors that engage more deeply and successfully with specific scientific topics. Not only was this course not a gut, but it also didn't facilitate student learning/engagement to the degree necessary to both succeed in and enjoy the course.
I would recommend this course to other students because it is an interesting way to learn more about biology within a social context.
yes
I would definitely recommend this course to other non-STEM majors looking for an interesting introduction to molecular biology.
Only take this is you have to.
Would recommend this source to non-STEM students who are willing to learn the biology behind relevant topics

Would recommend to non-STEM majors looking for a science credit. There are probably easier classes to get that credit, but this class definitely teaches you a lot that will last with you. Problem sets can be graded harshly at times, so definitely discuss them with other students/teaching fellows before submitting.
Not really. I think it was marketed as an intro bio course, but had expectations above one. If you have a strong science background youll be fine.
Yes! If you want a fairly easy science class with no tests and interesting topics, this is it.
yes, its important to learn about how your body works and this class take on very current topics/trends
Yes, this course is relatively fair and provides great insight into biology.

In general, this course would be a good option for non-STEM majors looking for science credits, but try to find a good discussion section and teaching fellow that works for you as they are not all the same experience by any means.
Yes! This is a great course for those who are looking for a science credit.

YES its a GREAT science class for non science students. It does ask you to actually pay attention to the material and to learn how to put together scientific sources, but it focuses on each week or two weeks having a single, contained theme rather than trying to have you retain info for the whole semester. The papers are super approachable and actually very good exercises in applying scientific literacy.
Yes, it covers a lot and is very interesting.
Absolutely. One of the few classes where you learn a ton, the workload is light, and its actually enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture.
all lectures were recorded and posted on canvas in addition to being held live on zoom
Mandatory discussion section
Section discussions, which took the format of virtual seminars
Virtual/recorded lecture as well as a discussion section
NA
Recorded lecture with live virtual section.
It was a combination of recorded lectures, live virtual lectures, and virtual discussion sections.
Live and recorded
Section
At first, I attended the live virtual lectures. Midway through the semester, I attended the recorded lectures. At that point, my only live engagement with the course was discussion sessions.
virtual sections
N/A
virtual discussion section
Live virtual lectures with 5 different professors covering different topics.
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Virtual discussion section
Virtual discussion section
Section once weekly and biweekly lectures
We also had live virtual sections discussions every week for 50 min in addition to the live virtual lectures
The course was a recorded lecture and Zoom-based synchronous discussion section
Additional virtual weekly discussion sections.
Discussion sections with teaching fellows weekly.
We had a combination of live virtual lectures and virtual discussion sections.
Recorded lectures, live virtual lectures, and discussion sections
Live virtual discussion sections.
virtual section
section
This course had a live virtual lecture with discussion sections.
Virtual, optionally synchronous lectures and mandatory, synchronous section
None.
Weekly section

extras.title:
MB&B 105 01/MCDB 105 01
        Biology, the World, and Us
